thread.title: Stalled Export-Import Bank to get a House vote
thread.title_full: Stalled Export-Import Bank to get a House vote | The Columbus Dispatch

author: The Columbus Dispatch
title: Stalled Export-Import Bank to get a House vote
text:
WASHINGTON – Republicans Pat Tiberi of Genoa Township and Steve Stivers of Upper Arlington and Democrat Joyce Beatty of Jefferson Township joined a majority of House members Friday to force a floor vote later this month to re-authorize a federal agency which helps U.S. companies export their goods.

By doing so, they defied a small group of conservatives led by Republican Jim Jordan of Urbana who have staunchly opposed renewing the U.S. Export-Import Bank, which provides credit to foreign companies buying American products. 

The move was a major victory for U.S. companies such as General Electric and Boeing Aircraft which have insisted they need the bank to compete abroad with foreign companies. 

The 218 House members relied on a rare parliamentary technique known as a “discharge petition” to keep the bank alive. The petition requires the bill to be placed on the House floor, where it has the votes to pass.

Stivers, an ally of House Speaker John Boehner, R-West Chester, said “the Export Import Bank is critical for protecting and growing U.S. jobs, and it generates a profit for our government.”

“There is overwhelming, bipartisan support for reforming and reauthorizing the bank,” Stivers said.

House Minority Whip Steny Hoyer, D-Md., said “thanks to this discharge petition, the House is able to work its will, I am confident that it will join the Senate in expressing its overwhelming bipartisan support to reopen” the bank.

Michael Needham, chief executive officer for the conservative non-profit organization Heritage Action Fund — which opposes the bank — accused Boehner and “a few dozen GOP pawns” of corporate lobbyists of working with House Democrats to save the bank.

Even though the Senate overwhelmingly voted to re-authorize the bank earlier this year, the Senate will have to give its approval again once the House passes the measure.

The House’s failure to renew the bank has appalled large and small U.S. companies whose executives contend they rely on the bank’s credit and insurance to help them sell their goods abroad. GE Aviation in suburban Cincinnati has been particularly critical of Jordan and Gov. John Kasich for opposing renewal of the bank.

Between 2007 and 2014, more than 360 Ohio companies relied on credit guarantees provided by the bank to export $3 billion worth of products.
